news_summary: Advancements in laser technology have revealed new properties of common metals, while Google's use of billions of mobile phones enhances global earthquake detection and alert systems.
news_summary_fr: Les progrès de la technologie laser ont révélé de nouvelles propriétés de métaux courants, tandis que l'utilisation par Google de milliards de téléphones mobiles améliore la détection des tremblements de terre et les systèmes d'alerte au niveau mondial.
news_summary_es: Los avances en tecnología láser han revelado nuevas propiedades de metales comunes, mientras que el uso de miles de millones de teléfonos móviles por parte de Google mejora los sistemas mundiales de detección y alerta de terremotos.

articles.title: Lasers just unlocked a hidden side of gold, copper, and aluminum
articles.summary: Scientists have cracked a century-old physics mystery by detecting magnetic signals in non-magnetic metals using only light and a revamped laser technique. Previously undetectable, these faint magnetic “whispers” are now measurable, revealing hidden patterns of electron behavior. The breakthrough could revolutionize how we explore magnetism in everyday materials—without bulky instruments or wires—and may open new doors for quantum computing, memory storage, and advanced electronics.
articles.content:
A team of scientists has developed a powerful new way to detect subtle magnetic signals in common metals like copper, gold, and aluminum—using nothing more than light and a clever technique. Their research, recently published in the prestigious journal Nature Communications, could pave the way for advances in everything from smartphones to quantum computing.

The Longstanding Puzzle: Why Can’t We See the Optical Hall Effect?

For over a century, scientists have known that electric currents bend in a magnetic field—a phenomenon known as the Hall effect. In magnetic materials like iron, this effect is strong and well understood. But in ordinary, non-magnetic metals like copper or gold, the effect is much weaker.

In theory, a related phenomenon—the optical Hall effect—should help scientists visualize how electrons behave when light and magnetic fields interact. But at visible wavelengths, this effect has remained far too subtle to detect. The scientific world has known it was there, but lacked the tools to measure it.

“It was like trying to hear a whisper in a noisy room for decades,” said Prof. Amir Capua. “Everyone knew the whisper was there, but we didn’t have a microphone sensitive enough to hear it.”

Cracking the Code: A Closer Look at the Invisible

Led by Ph.D. candidate Nadav Am Shalom and Prof. Amir Capua from the Institute of Electrical Engineering and Applied Physics at Hebrew University, in collaboration with Prof. Binghai Yan from the Weizmann Institute of Science, Pennsylvania State University, and Prof. Igor Rozhansky from the University of Manchester, the study focuses on a tricky challenge in physics: how to detect tiny magnetic effects in materials that aren’t magnetic.

“You might think of metals like copper and gold as magnetically ‘quiet’—they don’t stick to your fridge like iron does,” explained Prof. Capua. “But in reality, under the right conditions, they do respond to magnetic fields—just in extremely subtle ways.”

The challenge has always been how to detect these tiny effects—especially using light in the visible spectrum where laser sources are readily available. Until now, the signal was simply too faint to observe.

Turning Up the Volume on Magnetic Whispers

To solve this, the researchers upgraded a method called the magneto-optical Kerr effect (MOKE), which uses a laser to measure how magnetism alters light’s reflection. Think of it like using a high-powered flashlight to catch the faintest glint off a surface in the dark.

By combining a 440-nanometer blue laser with large-amplitude modulation of the external magnetic field, they dramatically boosted the technique’s sensitivity. The result: they were able to pick up magnetic “echoes” in non-magnetic metals like copper, gold, aluminum, tantalum, and platinum—a feat previously considered near-impossible.

Why It Matters: When Noise Becomes a Signal

The Hall effect is a pivotal tool in the semiconductor industry and in studying materials at the atomic scale: it helps scientists figure out how many electrons are in a metal. But traditionally, measuring the Hall effect means physically attaching tiny wires to the device, a process that is time-consuming and tricky, especially when dealing with nanometer-sized components. The new approach, however, is much simpler: it merely requires to shine a laser on the electrical device, no wires needed.

Digging deeper, the team found that what appeared to be random “noise” in their signal wasn’t random at all. Instead, it followed a clear pattern tied to a quantum property called spin-orbit coupling, which links how electrons move to how they spin—a key behavior in modern physics.

This connection also affects how magnetic energy dissipates in materials. These insights have direct implications for the design of magnetic memory, spintronic devices, and even quantum systems.

“It’s like discovering that static on a radio isn’t just interference—it’s someone whispering valuable information,” said Ph.D. candidate Am Shalom. “We’re now using light to ‘listen’ to these hidden messages from electrons.”

Looking Ahead: A New Window into Spin and Magnetism

The technique offers a non-invasive, highly sensitive tool for exploring magnetism in metals—without the need for massive magnets or cryogenic conditions. Its simplicity and precision could help engineers build faster processors, more energy-efficient systems, and sensors with unprecedented accuracy.

“This research turns a nearly 150-year-old scientific problem into a new opportunity,” said Prof. Capua.

“Interestingly, even Edwin Hall, the greatest scientists of all, who discovered the Hall effect, attempted to measure his effect using a beam of light with no success. He summarizes in the closing sentence of his notable paper from 1881: “I think that, if the action of silver had been one tenth as strong as that of iron, the effect would have been detected. No such effect was observed.” (E. Hall, 1881).”

“By tuning in to the right frequency—and knowing where to look—we’ve found a way to measure what was once thought invisible.”
articles.reasoning: This article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in detecting magnetic signals in common metals using lasers, which could revolutionize electronics, quantum computing, and memory storage. It highlights progress in technology that promises practical benefits and advances in understanding fundamental physics, offering hope for future innovations.
articles.personality_title: Lasers reveal hidden magnetic signals in everyday metals
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
For more than 100 years, scientists have struggled to detect tiny magnetic signals in common metals like gold, copper, and aluminum. These metals don’t show strong magnetism, making it hard to study their electron behavior with traditional tools.

**What happened**
A team of scientists created a new laser technique that uses only light to spot these faint magnetic “whispers” in non-magnetic metals. By shining lasers in a clever way, they can now measure subtle magnetic patterns that were invisible before.

**Impact**
This discovery opens up a new way to study magnetism without bulky devices or wires. It could lead to better electronics, improved memory storage, and advances in quantum computing by helping us understand and control electrons in everyday materials.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to refine this laser method and explore how it can be applied to develop smarter, faster technologies. They also hope to uncover more about the mysterious magnetic behaviors inside metals.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Using light and lasers, scientists have unlocked hidden magnetic signals in common metals, paving the way for exciting technological breakthroughs.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les lasers révèlent des signaux magnétiques cachés dans les métaux courants
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Depuis plus de 100 ans, les scientifiques peinent à détecter de faibles signaux magnétiques dans des métaux courants comme l’or, le cuivre et l’aluminium. Ces métaux ne montrent pas de magnétisme fort, ce qui rend l’étude de leur comportement électronique difficile avec les outils traditionnels.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Une équipe de chercheurs a créé une nouvelle technique laser qui utilise uniquement la lumière pour repérer ces faibles « chuchotements » magnétiques dans des métaux non magnétiques. En utilisant les lasers de manière astucieuse, ils peuvent désormais mesurer des motifs magnétiques subtils auparavant invisibles.

**Impact**
Cette découverte offre une nouvelle façon d’étudier le magnétisme sans appareils encombrants ni fils. Cela pourrait améliorer l’électronique, le stockage de mémoire et faire avancer l’informatique quantique en nous aidant à comprendre et contrôler les électrons dans des matériaux courants.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient de perfectionner cette méthode laser et d’explorer ses applications pour développer des technologies plus intelligentes et rapides. Ils espèrent aussi en apprendre davantage sur les comportements magnétiques mystérieux à l’intérieur des métaux.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
Grâce à la lumière et aux lasers, les scientifiques ont dévoilé des signaux magnétiques cachés dans des métaux courants, ouvrant la voie à des avancées technologiques passionnantes.
articles.personality_title_es: Los láseres revelan señales magnéticas ocultas en metales comunes
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Durante más de 100 años, los científicos han luchado por detectar pequeñas señales magnéticas en metales comunes como el oro, el cobre y el aluminio. Estos metales no muestran magnetismo fuerte, lo que dificulta estudiar su comportamiento electrónico con herramientas tradicionales.

**Qué pasó**
Un equipo de científicos desarrolló una nueva técnica con láser que utiliza solo luz para detectar estos débiles «susurros» magnéticos en metales no magnéticos. Al usar los láseres de manera ingeniosa, ahora pueden medir patrones magnéticos sutiles que antes eran invisibles.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento abre una nueva forma de estudiar el magnetismo sin dispositivos voluminosos ni cables. Podría mejorar la electrónica, el almacenamiento de memoria y avanzar en la computación cuántica al ayudarnos a entender y controlar los electrones en materiales comunes.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean perfeccionar este método láser y explorar cómo aplicarlo para desarrollar tecnologías más inteligentes y rápidas. También esperan descubrir más sobre los misteriosos comportamientos magnéticos dentro de los metales.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Usando luz y láseres, los científicos han desbloqueado señales magnéticas ocultas en metales comunes, abriendo camino a emocionantes avances tecnológicos.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm drawing of glowing golden, copper, and silver metallic surfaces gently illuminated by a soft blue laser beam, with delicate shimmering waves and subtle magnetic ripples weaving through the metals like invisible threads of light, set against a calm, neutral background.

articles.title: Google tapped billions of mobile phones to detect quakes worldwide — and send alerts
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 17 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02278-3Study reveals how the tech behemoth is using the motions sensors on phones to expand quake warnings to more countries.
articles.content:
Technology giant Google harnessed motion sensors on more than two billion mobile phones between 2021 and 2024 to detect earthquakes, and then sent automated warnings to millions of people in 98 countries. In an analysis of the data, released in Science today1, Google’s scientists say that the technology captured more than 11,000 quakes and performed on a par with standard seismometers. Earthquake researchers who were not involved with the experiment are impressed by the system’s performance, but argue that public officials would need access to more information about the proprietary technology before relying on it.

AI predicts how many earthquake aftershocks will strike — and their strength

Over the past few decades, earthquake alert systems using standard seismometers have been deployed in locations including Mexico, Japan and the US west coast. But in 2020, Google announced that it would build a crowd-sourced system to detect tremors at their earliest stages by tracking the collective shaking of Android phones. The results from the first three years of operation, released today, show that the technology works and has improved over time. On average, thousands of people are killed by earthquakes each year, and with the mobile-based alert system in place, the number of people who now have access to earthquake alerts has increased tenfold since 2019, says Google.

“It’s very impressive: most countries don’t have an earthquake early-warning system, and this can help provide that service,” says Allen Husker, a seismologist at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. But, Husker says, he would feel better if Google would provide independent scientists with more access to the data and algorithms.

When a large quake hits, Google sends an urgent ‘TakeAction’ message to Android phones.Credit: Google

Scientists at Google say they are being as transparent as they can be about how the system works and performs. Owing to privacy concerns, sharing raw data from users’ phones is a challenge, they told Nature, but the Science paper is designed to shed as much light as possible on how the system works.

“That really is the origin of this paper,” says Richard Allen, a seismologist at the University of California, Berkeley, and visiting faculty member at Google. “I hope the community will recognize that and appreciate that.”

Crowd-sourced detection

The Android Earthquake Alerts system relies on quantity, not quality: research-grade seismometers provide higher quality data, but Google is relying on the ubiquity of modern Android smartphones — which collect and report motion data by default, unless users opt out — to get around a lack of sensitivity in any given device. In addition to mapping out data from individual users to identify earthquake origins and strength, the Google team developed algorithms to analyse the collected signals, which contain regional differences owing to geology and building construction, and account for how various phone models register motion.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a technological breakthrough where Google uses billions of mobile phones to detect earthquakes and send alerts, significantly expanding early warning coverage worldwide. This innovation has the potential to save lives by providing timely alerts to millions of people in countries that previously lacked such systems. Despite some concerns about data transparency, the overall impact is positive and hopeful.
articles.personality_title: Google uses billions of phones to spot earthquakes and warn millions
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Earthquakes can strike suddenly and cause serious damage. Early warnings help people stay safe, but many countries don’t have systems to detect quakes quickly.

**What happened**
Google used motion sensors in over two billion mobile phones from 2021 to 2024 to sense earthquakes. When a quake was detected, the system sent automatic alerts to millions in 98 countries. This approach worked as well as traditional earthquake monitors.

**Impact**
Thanks to this technology, millions of people in places without early warning systems now get timely alerts. This can help them take safety measures and potentially save lives. Experts are excited about how well the phone-based system performs.

**What's next step**
Google and researchers aim to improve the system further and expand coverage. They also want to address concerns about data transparency to ensure people’s trust while keeping the alerts effective.

**One-sentence takeaway**
By turning billions of phones into quake detectors, Google is helping protect millions worldwide with faster earthquake warnings.
articles.personality_title_fr: Google utilise des milliards de téléphones pour détecter les séismes et avertir des millions de personnes
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les séismes surviennent soudainement et peuvent causer de lourds dégâts. Les alertes précoces aident à rester en sécurité, mais beaucoup de pays n’ont pas de systèmes rapides pour détecter les tremblements de terre.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Google a utilisé les capteurs de mouvement de plus de deux milliards de téléphones mobiles entre 2021 et 2024 pour détecter les séismes. Lorsqu’un tremblement de terre était détecté, le système envoyait automatiquement des alertes à des millions de personnes dans 98 pays. Cette méthode a montré une efficacité comparable aux moniteurs sismiques traditionnels.

**Impact**
Grâce à cette technologie, des millions de personnes dans des régions sans système d’alerte précoce reçoivent désormais des notifications rapides. Cela leur permet de prendre des mesures de sécurité et peut sauver des vies. Les experts saluent la performance de ce système basé sur les téléphones.

**Prochaine étape**
Google et les chercheurs veulent améliorer encore le système et étendre sa couverture. Ils souhaitent aussi répondre aux questions sur la transparence des données pour renforcer la confiance du public tout en gardant les alertes efficaces.

**À retenir en une phrase**
En transformant des milliards de téléphones en détecteurs de séismes, Google aide à protéger des millions de personnes dans le monde grâce à des alertes plus rapides.
articles.personality_title_es: Google utiliza miles de millones de teléfonos para detectar terremotos y alertar a millones
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los terremotos ocurren de repente y pueden causar daños graves. Las alertas tempranas ayudan a mantener a las personas seguras, pero muchos países no tienen sistemas para detectarlos rápido.

**Qué pasó**
Google usó los sensores de movimiento de más de dos mil millones de teléfonos móviles entre 2021 y 2024 para detectar terremotos. Cuando se detectaba uno, el sistema enviaba alertas automáticas a millones en 98 países. Este método funcionó tan bien como los monitores sísmicos tradicionales.

**Impacto**
Gracias a esta tecnología, millones de personas en lugares sin sistemas de alerta temprana ahora reciben avisos a tiempo. Esto les permite tomar medidas de seguridad y puede salvar vidas. Los expertos están impresionados con el desempeño del sistema basado en teléfonos.

**Próximo paso**
Google y los investigadores buscan mejorar el sistema y ampliar su cobertura. También quieren abordar preocupaciones sobre la transparencia de los datos para asegurar la confianza del público manteniendo la efectividad de las alertas.

**Resumen en una frase**
Al convertir miles de millones de teléfonos en detectores de terremotos, Google ayuda a proteger a millones en todo el mundo con alertas más rápidas.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a glowing network of diverse mobile phones scattered across a peaceful global map, their screens softly pulsing like gentle heartbeats to symbolize collective motion sensing, connected by flowing, translucent lines representing data sharing, set against a calm natural palette of blues, greens, and soft earth tones.
